Award.AwardTitle: Genomics of adaptation to agriculture in Striga hermonthica, a plant parasite of cereals
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF National Plant Genome Initiative Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2017. The fellowship supports a research and training plan in a host laboratory for the Fellow who also presents a plan to broaden participation in biology. The host institution for the fellowship is Pennsylvania State University and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Jesse Lasky.

Agronomic weeds pose a serious threat to agricultural productivity, and weed infestations may intensify under changing climates. To better understand interactions between biotic and abiotic stressors, this project investigates mechanisms of specialization to different host crops and abiotic environments in purple witchweed (Striga hermonthica). Parasitic witchweeds constitute the greatest biotic constraint to food production in sub-Saharan Africa and devastate yields of economically important cereals such as maize, sorghum, millet, and rice. Broader impacts include generation of new genomic and phenotypic resources to enhance development of resistant crop varieties, training of undergraduate students, and workshops in witchweed bioinformatics targeted to African scientists. Training objectives include statistical evolutionary genomics, ancient DNA sequencing, quantitative genetics, and experimental plant-parasite interactions.

The main goal of this project is to better understand evolution of crop-parasite interactions across diverse abiotic environments. First, genomic signatures of host-specialization and local adaptation will be identified, using targeted exome sequencing of 200 herbarium specimens collected within the past 150 years from different hosts of origin across East and West Africa. Loci will be identified that exhibit statistical associations with environment and host of origin, with allelic variation that tracks change in regional host crop production over time. For the second aim, effects of abiotic stress on host range will be experimentally evaluated. Seed germination, early host-seeking behavior, and host resistance will be quantified under nitrogen- and water-limitation for 20 parasite populations across 60 genotypes of three agriculturally important host crops: sorghum, millet, and maize. Genomic and phenotypic resources generated during the project will be publicly accessible through online databases (NCBI; Project Unity, http://phenome-networks.com) and a dedicated project website including instructional materials, code, and molecular protocols.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pests greatly limit crop production, but we still know little about how crops and parasites coevolve in agricultural ecosystems. In contrast to natural plant communities, parasites in crop fields are usually expected to gain the upper hand in coevolutionary "arms races" because genetic diversity of host crops in cultivation is often very limited. This project developed a framework to characterize associations between variation in genomes of traditional varieties of the staple crop sorghum with the distribution of the parasitic weed Striga hermonthica, a major constraint to global food security. We found that parasite occurrence is strongly linked to presence of genetic resistance mechanisms in traditional varieties of sorghum cultivated across Africa.

In addition to highlighting an important role of host adaptation in smallholder farming systems, our approach revealed genes that may be important for resistance to parasites. One gene strongly linked to high parasite occurrence was described in a previous study as causing resistance due to changes in the structure of plant hormones. These hormones, emitted by host roots, are used by parasites to sense hosts, but they are also important for a multitude of other functions. Using genome-editing technology, we found that change in hormone structure led to a growth trade-off, possibly due to downregulation of numerous light-harvesting genes and the importance of the hormone as a regulator of photosynthesis.  Resistance of genome-edited sorghum further depended on parasite population and abiotic environment. These findings emphasize the complexity of host-parasite-environment interactions and the utility of eco-evolutionary perspectives to inform plant breeding. 

The research activities supported by this project have had broader impacts including development of interdisciplinary analysis frameworks for understanding host-parasite coevolution, generation of new genomic resources for parasitic plants (whole genome sequencing data for 70 S. hermonthica samples at 10x depth; data currently being analyzed for publication), and fostering international collaboration among researchers from natural history museums, academia, and industry. Support from this Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology enabled the PI to serve as the US-government supported partner on a proposal funded by the USAID PEER program "Deploying Striga Smart Sorghum: The Last Mile" to collaborator S.M. Runo (Kenyatta University, Kenya), which will be supported by data and analyses developed as part of this NSF award. The fellow will lead a workshop focused on mapping resistance and virulence alleles in R in Nairobi, Kenya (rescheduled for summer 2021 due to COVID-19).  In addition to advanced training of the fellow in machine learning, spatial ecology, and experimental plant biology, this fellowship supported mentorship of two undergraduate students and two rotating graduate students in bioinformatics and parasitic plant biology.
